awd_titl_txt: Does Proximity of Hydraulic Fracturing and Wastewater Disposal to Basement Increase the Likelihood of Induced Seismicity in the Central and Eastern US?
awd_abstract_narration:
Does Proximity of Hydraulic Fracturing and Wastewater Disposal to Geologic Basement Rocks Increase the Likelihood of Seismicity in the Central and Eastern US?

Over the past decade, the increased use of enhanced oil and gas recovery operations is thought to be largely responsible for a dramatic rise in earthquakes in the in the Central and Eastern US.  However, some areas that have experienced such an increase, such as in Pennsylvania and North Dakota, appear to have little if any earthquakes related to these operations.  This study seeks to better understand these geographic differences by examining whether the subsurface proximity of oil and gas operations to geologic basement rocks promotes earthquakes.  Located a few miles below the surface, the basement is comprised of igneous and metamorphic rocks that can contain numerous ancient faults.   Both hydraulic fracturing and wastewater disposal operations result in deep fluid injection occurring close to the basement may have the potential to reactivate these basement faults, producing earthquakes.  This study seeks to test this idea by improving earthquake detection, refining knowledge of how deep the basement is, and comparing these to the geographic location, depth, and timing of oil and gas operations.  In particular, the researchers will apply new processing of seismic data to better detect small earthquakes, compile detailed records of well operations from state databases, and produce regional basement-depth maps across the Central and Eastern US.  To accomplish these goals, this project will leverage new approaches to developing large-scale undergraduate research involvement.  This project will also increase knowledge transfer with geologic surveys, state regulators, and the oil and gas industry.  The researchers will continue to build on a track record of public outreach including proactive dissemination and discussion with the news media considering the national debate over hydraulic fracturing.  

To improve the detection of induced seismicity, this research will first employ a template matching approach that has successfully discerned induced from natural earthquakes.  This research will also utilize an emerging technology for detecting the repetitive microseismic swarms commonly associated with induced events, without requiring a previously cataloged earthquake as a template.  These approaches will be employed on seismic stations throughout the Central and Eastern US and will provide a more uniform detection of induced seismicity.  To improve basement depth characterization, this research will integrate recently constructed basement maps, particularly those by state geological surveys and regional compilations.  Deep wells will also help characterize geology between injection/hydraulic fracturing target intervals and basement to determine if the mechanical properties of these subsurface rocks may influence the occurrence of induced earthquakes.  This project will actively engage state geologic surveys in the Central and Eastern US to accomplish the project goals.  In some cases our research will benefit from existing basement, geologic, or seismicity characterizations performed by state geological surveys and other agencies.  In other cases we expect to generate and contribute this information to these institutions.  Geologic surveys are also key communicators to the general public, so this research will capitalize on the opportunities to integrate new results from this project with existing educational resources that these state surveys already provide.  This project will also utilize new undergraduate curricular structures to introduce foundational research concepts early in a student?s college career to engage a larger number of students in research project such as this one.  Mentoring will be formalized to establish thematic research teams focused on the project goals.  The results will be disseminate with and beyond the academic community, continuing to engage industry and regulators as well as the general public.

por.por_cntn:
The increase in enhanced oil and gas extraction is generally accepted to be largely responsible for a dramatic rise in seismicity in the Central and Eastern U.S. over the past decade.  However, certain areas that have experienced large increases in oil and gas operations have resulted in very little if any seismicity.  Previous research has been divided on whether the proximity of the oil and gas operations to deeper, older rocks known as the basement influences why earthquakes occur in some places but not others.  To investigate the potential proximity relationship, this project developed earthquake detection tools using high performance computing and machine learning to better analyze the seismicity patterns in relation to human operations.  In addition, vast amounts of oil and gas well information were collected regarding injection and extraction activities as well as evidence to estimate the depth of the basement rock layers.  This analysis revealed human induced earthquake swarms differ from natural earthquake sequences in stable continental regions, revealing that both hydraulic fracturing and wastewater disposal operations induce these characteristic seismic swarms.  The resulting patterns showed the proximity of industrial operations to the basement rock layer is correlated with seismicity across nearly a dozen states of the Central and Eastern U.S., indicating this factor can be used to evaluate likelihood of human induced seismicity. Detailed examinations of earthquakes induced by hydraulic fracturing indicated that the geologic maturity of nearby faults plays a key role in the types of seismicity that are produced and whether it can be detected with typical seismic recording instruments. In this context, the basement represents a proxy for where the mature faults are in stable continental regions.   In addition to this primary relationship, statistical modeling of our observations suggests the probability of induced seismicity can also be influenced by several aspects of the injection including the volume, viscosity, target depth, rock layer, and the number of adjacent wells.  These findings were facilitated by the discovery that hydraulic fracturing has induced thousands of earthquakes over broad areas of Oklahoma and Texas.  Detailed investigations across the different study regions indicate that the injection flux (volume per day per area) plays a particularly important role in the probability of seismicity.  For example, when multiple wells in close proximity are injecting at the same time, the chance of seismicity is increased by 200-300% compared to other injection strategies.  These findings have been shared with the scientific community, but more importantly, they have been used by numerous companies and state regulators to inform best practices for harvesting energy resources while reducing the earthquake hazard.

This project also investigated strategies for improving geoscience education and outreach.  At the broadest scale, this project examined the popular earthquake ground motion visualizations seen by millions of people on social media and whether they help viewers understand basic seismic waves concepts.  This study discovered that it helped undergraduate geoscience majors, but it caused confusion for students without a geoscience background, implying that the visualization should be modified to increase understanding for the general public.  Seeking to help K-12 geoscience instruction, this project also investigated strategies for using visualizations of the motion of GPS instruments to illustrate the concept of elastic rebound that causes earthquakes.  This study determined the best strategy for improving understanding and identified several key misconceptions such as students struggling with the concept that rocks bend.  In order to improve undergraduate research experiences, this project developed a student self-reflection guide to better facilitate and recognize skill development, which was shared with other institutions running undergraduate research programs.  Finally, this project documented the development of an active-learning online course for introductory geology several years prior to the COVID-19 pandemic.  It demonstrates that a purposeful design of an online course that involves students in daily tutorial-based assignments with feedback can improve student performance on tasks involving key geoscience concepts.  This instructional approach was then adapted to provide asynchronous geoscience computing tutorials as part of the orientation and training for undergraduate research experiences.  When the COVID-19 pandemic forced course to rapidly shift to online formats in early 2020, these findings and approaches were shared broadly to provide guidance to instructors.  In addition, the online geoscience computing tutorials provided an important blueprint for the development of a 3-month skill building workshop offered in the summer 2020 to over 750 undergraduates.  This free, open, online opportunity had remarkably high retention and satisfaction rates for a training with this format.  It also diversified participation leading to ~30% enrollment from underrepresented minority groups and ~30% from non-geoscience majors.
